description.narrative: Summary: The project aims to increase agricultural productivity and economic empowerment among 1,200 young female farmers in Chiradzulu District.Through intensive trainings the participating farmers will be equipped with the skills, knowledge and hands-on experience enabling her/him to increase productivity of crops and livestock, practice small-scale irrigation, and process food for adding value and making the products more marketable

The primary target group is young female farmers. Women have been selected as a priority group because of the disproportionate impact that poverty has on women in all its forms. To achieving MDG 3 requires a change for women. The project will both empower the participating female farmers via the program as well as include men in the process. Men from the individual households ( spouses, brothers or fathers) will be invited for demonstrations in the club demonstration gardens, for agriculture shows, for workshops together with the participating females on health, nutrition, budgeting and planning – as well as for discussions on “gender” issues in the families.

The project activities will take all take their point of departure in the Clubs which will have 50 farmers in each. 50 members constitute a Club. 6 Clubs constitute a Cluster headed by 1 Farming Instructor. The Farming Instructor trains, instructs and ensures program implementation. Then proposed project will have 24 clubs and 4 Clusters. The 4 Clusters are headed and supervised by a Project Manage. Finally based at DAPP National Headquarter the Program Coordinator oversees the entire program, management and implementation. Each Club is the corner stone in the sustainability of the activities. Each Club chooses its own committee of 5 members.
The project goal: Social and economic women empowerment through training of 1,200 women farmers.
